awd_titl_txt: Change in Departments and Institutions via Active Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to address the national call for broader student participation and success in mathematics-intensive fields. It will do so by organizing a conference focused on improving undergraduate mathematics education. Over the past five years, studies of undergraduate calculus education have shown that many undergraduate students who initially express interest in STEM majors, become disheartened and change to non-STEM majors after completing a calculus course. To address the need for increased student success in STEM, many efforts have focused on improving instructional practices and high failure rates in the calculus sequence, in particular for underrepresented groups including women and students of color. Such efforts have inspired mathematics departments and university administrators to try to improve mathematics instruction through professional development, course coordination, instructional materials, and student supports. This conference will develop and expand a network of partners to include researchers, mathematics faculty, and administrators.  It will also encourage and support data-informed improvement efforts in undergraduate calculus education and document lessons learned to share nationally.

The conference organizing committee has worked with undergraduate mathematics departments through the NSF-funded Progress through Calculus (DUE-1430540) and Student Engagement in Mathematics through an Institutional Network for Active Learning (DUE-1624643, 1624610, 1624628, and 1624639).  These efforts identified a strong interest among mathematics faculty in participating in a Networked Improvement Community that shares resources, data, and lessons learned regarding implementing and sustaining active learning in the calculus sequence. Sustaining and expanding such efforts requires significant shifts in departmental culture. To this end, the conference has three main goals: (1) Connect conference participants to an existing community of mathematics faculty, researchers, and administrators dedicated to educational innovation in Precalculus through Calculus 2 courses; (2) Leverage these connections to share and generate knowledge of strategies for initiating, implementing, and sustaining cultural change that supports the improvement of courses in the calculus sequence; and (3) Foster instructor development by encouraging participants to share highly effective instructional practices and tasks for an active learning classroom. Speakers from different institutions will share their research during concurrent workshop sessions focused on four major themes: attention to equity, diversity and inclusivity in the classroom; departmental culture and change strategies; course and curriculum redesign; and professional development. These sessions will actively involve attendees, reflecting the conference’s commitment to the use of evidence-based instructional practices to best support learning. In addition to the sessions, there will be a panel of university administrators who have supported successful change efforts, to engage participants in a discussion on how to leverage administrator support when making changes to the calculus sequence. There will also be two plenary sessions to focus on issues of equity, institutional change, and the roles of faculty and administrators. This project is funded by the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Change in Departments and Institutions via Active Learning (Change DIAL) promotes the growth of a network of mathematics faculty dedicated to improving student success in lower-division college mathematics courses. The Change DIAL conference connects participants to an existing community of mathematics faculty, researchers, and administrators dedicated to educational innovation in precalculus to calculus courses. Change DIAL researchers leverage these connections to share and generate knowledge of strategies for initiating, implementing, and sustaining cultural change to improve these courses as well as foster instructor development by encouraging the participants to share highly effective instructional practices and tasks for an active learning classroom.

 

Since the launch of the grant in 2020, the format of the conferences has evolved each year. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the 2020 conference was scaled back to only participants from the Student Engagement in Mathematics through an Institutional Network for Active Learning grant (SEMINAL), another related National Science Foundation project. The June 3-5, 2020 conference welcomed 65 registered participants via Zoom, featured keynotes and breakout sessions, and focused on the use of data to broaden participation in STEM fields and move toward more equitable student outcomes.

 

Built on the successes and lessons learned from the 2020 virtual conference, Change DIAL developed a virtual four-part summer workshop series for 2021 centered on four themes: equity, networks and building communities, impacts of COVID on active learning, and using data effectively. The 30 registered participants attended most of the sessions and were predominantly from SEMINAL. Each interactive session was facilitated by a team of at least six project leaders. The conference offered numerous opportunities for individual instructor development, specifically during the workshops focused on equity and the impacts of COVID-19 on active learning.

 

Change DIAL culminated with a hybrid conference May 23-25, 2022, with an in-person location of Lincoln, Nebraska. The conference was attended by 117 participants, 56 in-person and 61 online. The conference was highly interactive and built on themes from prior conferences to improve student success in first-year mathematics courses and broaden participation in STEM. Participation in the 2022 conference went far beyond SEMINAL; invitations were sent to members of a variety of national organizations. Sessions operated on timelines that allowed for both in-person and virtual participation and were organized by session themes of professional learning, task design, course design, and inclusive and equitable practices. Notes were taken at each session and shared with participants after the conference, as well as the slides from the presenters, in one synthesized notes document. These notes capture the high level of engagement by participants, showcasing active learning strategies that can be used in online, hybrid, and in-person spaces. Session facilitators shared several materials, including observation protocols that can be used to support instructors in reflecting on equity and deep mathematical engagement in their courses, tools for making sense of data, information about specific course design efforts (e.g., implementing a mastery-based grading system), and strategies for planning change efforts.
